subtasks: Determining the necessary expansion area for planting
Marking boundaries for the new field expansion
Clearing the designated expansion area of vegetation and debris
Preparing the ground by leveling and tilling the soil
Checking soil fertility and making adjustments as needed
Ensuring proper drainage and irrigation systems are in place
Planning crop rotations and seed selection for the expanded area
Guiding the cultivator through the rows to cultivate and turn over soil
Adjusting depth and width settings for optimal soil preparation
Observing the condition of the soil and making real-time adjustments
Ensuring even coverage and distribution of amendments (e.g., fertilizer, lime)
Potentially overseeding or applying cover crops for soil health
Preparing to attach the broadcast seeder to the 4WD tractor
Attaching the seeder properly onto the tractor's hitch
Conducting a test run to ensure proper engagement and safety
Setting the seeder to appropriate seed rate and spacing for the crop
Checking the seed hopper to ensure an adequate supply of seeds
Operating the tractor and seeder in a straight line to plant the seeds
Continuously monitoring the planting process to make adjustments
Clearing any seed jams or issues that may arise during planting
Selecting and attaching the appropriate fertilizer applicator
Calibrating the applicator to deliver the correct amount of fertilizer
Setting the spread pattern and coverage required for the field
Operating the tractor to apply fertilizer uniformly across the field
Keeping an eye on the applicator's performance during operation
Checking the field for any missed spots or over-application areas
Digging the planting holes with a tree planter or auger
Ensuring the depth and spacing of the holes are suitable for the tree species
Handling and unwrapping the tree before planting
Positioning the tree upright in the hole, checking for straightness
Backfilling the hole with soil, tamping it down to remove air pockets
Watering the tree to settle the soil and encourage root establishment
Mulching around the base of the tree to retain moisture and suppress weeds

tasks.task: Driving the tractor over damp soil to create a seed bed
subtasks: Ensuring the soil is sufficiently moist before rolling
Adjusting the tractor's speed to avoid compaction while rolling
Overlapping passes to ensure the entire field receives even compaction
Verifying the smoothness of the seed bed after rolling
Deciding on the crops to be planted based on market demand and soil suitability
Determining the appropriate seed varieties and quantities for each crop
Checking seed quality, viability, and certifications (e.g., organic)
Organizing the seeds in a logical order for planting
Making notes on planting depths, spacings, and recommended practices
Collecting soil samples from different parts of the field
Sending the samples to a lab for analysis
Reviewing the test results for pH, nutrient levels, and soil texture
Preparing a soil management plan based on test results

tasks.task: Using a GPS mapping system in the field
subtasks: Calibrating the GPS for accurate field mapping
Planning the rotation or planting pattern before moving to the field
Following the GPS guidance to plant rows accurately
Ensuring the GPS system's accuracy through real-time adjustments
Adjusting the corn planter settings for optimal seed placement
Loading the corn seed into the planter's seed box
Attaching the planter to the tractor and ensuring secure connections
Test driving to ensure proper seed drop and coverage
Planting the corn in straight, evenly spaced rows
Regularly inspecting the planter during operation for clogs or malfunctions

tasks.task: Checking for plants that did not emerge
subtasks: Walking the field to identify missing or weak plants
Marking the locations of the missed plants for replanting if necessary
Determining the reason for the missed or poor emergence (e.g., seed depth, soil moisture)
Adjusting the seed drill for proper depth and coverage for wheat seeds
Ensuring the drill is set to plant two seeds per spot for good germination
Operating the drill to plant the wheat in a precise pattern
Conducting a walk-through after planting to verify proper seed coverage
Choosing equipment suitable for rough terrain (e.g., tracked vehicles)
Adjusting machinery like cultivators and planters for uneven ground
Driving carefully to avoid tipping or damaging equipment
Monitoring soil compaction more closely on hills
Planting and managing crops accordingly to prevent erosion

tasks.task: Checking for weed growth in a soybean field
subtasks: Walking the field and visually inspecting each row for weeds
Noting the types and extent of weed infestations
Deciding on the appropriate weed management strategy (e.g., chemical, mechanical)
If using herbicides, applying them following the label directions
Ensuring coverage is even and the correct rates are applied
Using a grain wagon to transport harvested grain to the barn
Pulling the grain wagon to the appropriate location in the field
Opening the grain chute and directing the flow of grain into the wagon
Securing the grain wagon for transport and moving it to the desired storage area
Operating a grain auger to unload the wagon into storage bins or a grain elevator
Ensuring the correct gear is utilized when working in wet conditions
Allowing time for fields to dry slightly before potentially damaging equipment
Observing equipment for signs of wear due to wet conditions
Adjusting planting or harvesting speeds based on soil conditions
Cutting hay with a mower or conditioner
Collecting hay using a pickup or bailer
Transporting the hay to the storage area safely
Opening the trailer doors and securing the ramp or gate
Stepping into the trailer carefully to avoid tripping
Maneuvering into the trailer without blocking the doors
Exiting the trailer when done, closing the doors safely
Selecting cover crops that enhance soil health (e.g., legumes, grasses)
Adjusting the seed drill for small cover crop seeds
Planting the cover crops between cash crop rows
Following up with proper weed control if necessary
Walking through the field to assess the standing crops
Identifying crops that are leaning or down due to wind or disease
Deciding on the best course of action (e.g., harvest early, inject roots)
Setting the planter for proper depth and spacing for dry beans
Ensuring the seed cover is appropriate for the anticipated moisture
Operating the planter to plant the dry beans in the field
Collecting soil samples from various points in the field
Submitting the samples to a testing facility
Reviewing the test results to determine sulfur needs
Applying sulfur fertilizer as prescribed by the test

Selecting a suitable spot in the field, considering soil type and slope

Ensuring the sheep have adequate fencing and shelter
